articles.headline: Japanese Fret That Quality Is in Decline
articles.snippet: A recent surge in product recalls has set off fears in Japan that the country may be losing its edge to South Korea and China.
articles.abstract: A recent surge in product recalls has set off fears in Japan that the country may be losing its edge to South Korea and China.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Sept. 20 — Perhaps only in Japan could a television series like “Project X” have become one of the most popular TV shows. No, it isn’t a science fiction thriller. It’s about product quality.

articles.headline: Costly, Sure, but It’s Nirvana for TiVo Fans
articles.snippet: The TiVo Series 3 is meant to be the ultimate DVR, but how many people are willing to pay to bask in its glory?
articles.abstract: The TiVo Series 3 is meant to be the ultimate DVR, but how many people are willing to pay to bask in its glory?

articles.headline: Iran’s Leader Relishes 2nd Chance to Make Waves
articles.snippet: Iran’s president sparred with the Council on Foreign Relations, exasperating his questioners and angering the Bush administration and Jewish groups.
articles.abstract: Iran’s president sparred with the Council on Foreign Relations, exasperating his questioners and angering the Bush administration and Jewish groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Bush and his advisers decided to allow President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran into the country to address the United Nations, their strategy was simple: containment.

articles.headline: Flying Where Big Airlines Aren’t
articles.snippet: Allegiant Air has built a profitable strategy around the aging MD-80 jetliner, in yet another sign that traditional carriers remain vulnerable to low-cost competitors.
articles.abstract: Allegiant Air has built a profitable strategy around the aging MD-80 jetliner, in yet another sign that traditional carriers remain vulnerable to low-cost competitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gas guzzling and noisy, the MD-80 is the aging, seemingly indestructible jalopy of the skies.

articles.headline: At Los Angeles Times, a Civil Executive Rebellion
articles.snippet: Will the Tribune Company fire the publisher and editor at its biggest property and thereby risk a full-scale revolt?
articles.abstract: Will the Tribune Company fire the publisher and editor at its biggest property and thereby risk a full-scale revolt?
articles.byline: By Katharine Q. Seelye and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: Suits Say U.S. Impeded Audits for Oil Leases
articles.snippet: Auditors say the Interior Department suppressed efforts to recover millions from oil companies they said were cheating the government.
articles.abstract: Auditors say the Interior Department suppressed efforts to recover millions from oil companies they said were cheating the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 — Four government auditors who monitor leases for oil and gas on federal property say the Interior Department suppressed their efforts to recover millions of dollars from companies they said were cheating the government.

articles.headline: Only 25% in Poll Approve of the Congress
articles.snippet: The disregard for Congress is the most intense it has been since 1994, when the Democrats lost control of both houses, the latest Times/CBS News poll found.
articles.abstract: The disregard for Congress is the most intense it has been since 1994, when the Democrats lost control of both houses, the latest Times/CBS News poll found.
articles.lead_paragraph: With barely seven weeks until the midterm elections, Americans have an overwhelmingly negative view of the Republican-controlled Congress, with substantial majorities saying that they disapprove of the job it is doing and that its members do not deserve re-election, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Janet Elder

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Sheds Assets in Energy
articles.snippet: Amaranth Advisors is said to have sold its book of energy trades to J. P. Morgan and the Citadel Investment Group.
articles.abstract: Amaranth Advisors is said to have sold its book of energy trades to J. P. Morgan and the Citadel Investment Group.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that lost $5 billion betting on natural gas prices, sold its book of energy trades to J..P. Morgan and the Citadel Investment Group, according to two people briefed on the negotiations.

articles.headline: Fed Holds Rate Steady at 5.25%
articles.snippet: The move committed the Fed to the proposition that the slowing economy will eventually damp a still troublesome inflation rate.
articles.abstract: The move committed the Fed to the proposition that the slowing economy will eventually damp a still troublesome inflation rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 — The Federal Reserve’s policy makers voted Wednesday to keep interest rates unchanged, committing themselves for the second time in six weeks to the proposition that the slowing economy will eventually damp a still troublesome inflation rate.

articles.headline: Flying Where Big Airlines Aren’t
articles.snippet: Gas guzzling and noisy, the MD-80 is the aging, seemingly indestructible jalopy of the skies.     ''They fly forever,'' said Roger King, an aviation analyst at the research firm CreditSights. But with newer jetliners offering better fuel efficienc...
articles.abstract: Gas guzzling and noisy, the MD-80 is the aging, seemingly indestructible jalopy of the skies.     ''They fly forever,'' said Roger King, an aviation analyst at the research firm CreditSights. But with newer jetliners offering better fuel efficiency, a quieter ride and more comfort, the MD-80 is increasingly unloved by airlines. ''Everyone wants to get rid of them,'' Mr. King said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gas guzzling and noisy, the MD-80 is the aging, seemingly indestructible jalopy of the skies.

articles.headline: Fed Holds Rate Steady at 5.25%
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve's policy makers voted Wednesday to keep interest rates unchanged, committing themselves for the second time in six weeks to the proposition that the slowing economy will eventually damp a still troublesome inflation rate.     T...
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve's policy makers voted Wednesday to keep interest rates unchanged, committing themselves for the second time in six weeks to the proposition that the slowing economy will eventually damp a still troublesome inflation rate.     The vote was not unanimous; there was one dissent. But the tone of the statement -- issued in the early afternoon, after a morning of debate and voting -- suggested that the policy makers were clearly satisfied with the decision they made at their last meeting, on Aug. 8, to halt a series of 17 consecutive rate increases stretching back two years. It also suggested that they would not change their view at their next meeting in late October, just before the midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - The Federal Reserve's policy makers voted Wednesday to keep interest rates unchanged, committing themselves for the second time in six weeks to the proposition that the slowing economy will eventually damp a still troublesome inflation rate.

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Sheds Assets in Energy
articles.snippet: Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that lost $5 billion betting on natural gas prices, sold its book of energy trades to J. P. Morgan and the Citadel Investment Group, according to two people briefed on the negotiations.      The sale leaves Amaran...
articles.abstract: Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that lost $5 billion betting on natural gas prices, sold its book of energy trades to J. P. Morgan and the Citadel Investment Group, according to two people briefed on the negotiations.      The sale leaves Amaranth, once a well-regarded $9.25 billion fund, with $3.4 billion, down 55 percent from the beginning of the year and down 65 percent for September, according to a letter sent to investors late last night.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that lost $5 billion betting on natural gas prices, sold its book of energy trades to J. P. Morgan and the Citadel Investment Group, according to two people briefed on the negotiations.

articles.headline: Costly, Sure, but It’s Nirvana for TiVo Fans
articles.snippet: As any technophile can tell you, the best technology doesn't always become the dominant one. Just ask fans of the Macintosh, Minidisc or Betamax.      So imagine how fans of the TiVo must feel. Here's a machine that can time-shift, pause, and slic...
articles.abstract: As any technophile can tell you, the best technology doesn't always become the dominant one. Just ask fans of the Macintosh, Minidisc or Betamax.      So imagine how fans of the TiVo must feel. Here's a machine that can time-shift, pause, and slice and dice TV broadcasts, simplifying lives and family schedules all over the country. It's an elegant, refined device whose name, à la Google, has become a verb (''I'll TiVo it'').

articles.headline: At Los Angeles Times, a Civil Executive Rebellion
articles.snippet: After Jeffrey M. Johnson, the publisher of The Los Angeles Times, openly defied his bosses at the Tribune Company last week by refusing to make layoffs at the paper, he was summoned to Chicago and spent Tuesday meeting with top executives.     The...
articles.abstract: After Jeffrey M. Johnson, the publisher of The Los Angeles Times, openly defied his bosses at the Tribune Company last week by refusing to make layoffs at the paper, he was summoned to Chicago and spent Tuesday meeting with top executives.     The remarkable thing about the meeting, to Mr. Johnson's colleagues back in Los Angeles, was that he was not fired.
articles.byline: By Katharine Q. Seelye and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: Japanese Fret That Quality Is in Decline
articles.snippet: Perhaps only in Japan could a television series like ''Project X'' have become one of the most popular TV shows. No, it isn't a science fiction thriller. It's about product quality.     More specifically, it's about a bunch of corporate engineers ...
articles.abstract: Perhaps only in Japan could a television series like ''Project X'' have become one of the most popular TV shows. No, it isn't a science fiction thriller. It's about product quality.     More specifically, it's about a bunch of corporate engineers who invented the hand-held calculators and ink-jet printers that helped turn this nation into an industrial powerhouse.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Sept. 20 - Perhaps only in Japan could a television series like "Project X" have become one of the most popular TV shows. No, it isn't a science fiction thriller. It's about product quality.

articles.headline: Suits Say U.S. Impeded Audits for Oil Leases
articles.snippet: Four government auditors who monitor leases for oil and gas on federal property say the Interior Department suppressed their efforts to recover millions of dollars from companies they said were cheating the government.      The accusations, many o...
articles.abstract: Four government auditors who monitor leases for oil and gas on federal property say the Interior Department suppressed their efforts to recover millions of dollars from companies they said were cheating the government.      The accusations, many of them in four lawsuits that were unsealed last week by federal judges in Oklahoma, represent a rare rebellion by government investigators against their own agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - Four government auditors who monitor leases for oil and gas on federal property say the Interior Department suppressed their efforts to recover millions of dollars from companies they said were cheating the government.

articles.headline: Little Girl, 3 Million Years Old, Offers New Hints on Evolution
articles.snippet: If the fossil Lucy, the most famous woman from out of the deep human past, had a child, it might have looked a lot like the bundle of skull and bones uncovered by scientists digging in the badlands of Ethiopia.     The paleontologists who are anno...
articles.abstract: If the fossil Lucy, the most famous woman from out of the deep human past, had a child, it might have looked a lot like the bundle of skull and bones uncovered by scientists digging in the badlands of Ethiopia.     The paleontologists who are announcing the discovery in the journal Nature today said the 3.3-million-year-old fossils were of the earliest well-preserved child ever found in the human lineage. It was estimated to be about 3 years old at death, probably female and a member of the Australopithecus afarensis species, the same as Lucy's.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the fossil Lucy, the most famous woman from out of the deep human past, had a child, it might have looked a lot like the bundle of skull and bones uncovered by scientists digging in the badlands of Ethiopia.

articles.headline: Only 25% in Poll Approve of the Congress
articles.snippet: With barely seven weeks until the midterm elections, Americans have an overwhelmingly negative view of the Republican-controlled Congress, with substantial majorities saying that they disapprove of the job it is doing and that its members do not d...
articles.abstract: With barely seven weeks until the midterm elections, Americans have an overwhelmingly negative view of the Republican-controlled Congress, with substantial majorities saying that they disapprove of the job it is doing and that its members do not deserve re-election, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.     The disdain for Congress is as intense as it has been since 1994, when Republicans captured 52 seats to end 40 years of Democratic control of the House and retook the Senate as well. It underlines the challenge the Republican Party faces in trying to hold on to power in the face of a surge in anti-incumbent sentiment.
articles.lead_paragraph: With barely seven weeks until the midterm elections, Americans have an overwhelmingly negative view of the Republican-controlled Congress, with substantial majorities saying that they disapprove of the job it is doing and that its members do not deserve re-election, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Janet Elder

articles.headline: Iran’s Leader Relishes 2nd Chance to Make Waves
articles.snippet: When President Bush and his advisers decided to allow President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran into the country to address the United Nations, their strategy was simple: containment.      There would be no visits to other cities where he could denoun...
articles.abstract: When President Bush and his advisers decided to allow President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran into the country to address the United Nations, their strategy was simple: containment.      There would be no visits to other cities where he could denounce Washington or question Israel's legitimacy. There would be no opportunities, beyond his speech to the General Assembly, to turn questions about his nuclear intentions into repeated diatribes about America's nuclear arsenal.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Bush and his advisers decided to allow President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran into the country to address the United Nations, their strategy was simple: containment.
